when you put data in an index uh there is this this basic trade-off
that you do you it databases with indexes are fundamentally
uh built with this this trade-off where it it really is a lot of work to put the
data in uh and that makes it really quickly to
get the data out to search that's kind of the point of indexing um so that also means that it's really
built for low volume interest and high volume query
another aspect uh is this time space trade-off where um typically uh you'll see this that the
indexes are actually much much bigger anywhere from two to ten x the data that you're
putting in uh of course that's the time space trade off so you can you can stretch that um so the indexing that speeds up the
querying um is really what takes uh disk space and it also takes a lot of
cpu so when an index takes a step back really is like a like this
paper index you have in a library when i was a kid this was what an index would look like at the library
so you need an index and you need somewhere to store all the stuff that's indexed all the books right there on these sales
but in reality it really quickly becomes you know the indexes take most of the space and
there's really only that much space left on on your hard drives for storing the actual data
um so with an index free setup um you know the most naive would just be
appending to files and then because that's really really quick and
then you need to spend more cpu to get the data out because you need to go search for it so immediately
you see the data doesn't there's no because there's no index you save a lot on this space and you can use that disk
space to just store a lot extra data um so we easily get into replacement
